Business.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - Business section of LMT's content in bullet points:

• LMT is a global aerospace and defense company engaged in research, design, development, manufacture, integration, and sustainment of advanced technology systems, products, and services.
• The company serves both U.S. and international customers with products and services that have defense, civil, and commercial applications.
• LMT's principal customers are agencies of the U.S. Government.
• The company has 21st Century Security as its vision, aiming to accelerate the adoption of advanced networking technologies into the American defense enterprise.
• LMT is focusing on advancing all-domain mission solutions through investments in digital technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI)/Machine Learning (ML), Autonomy, and other capabilities.
• The company has well-established programs across its business segments that continue to experience growth, including F-35 sustainment activity, Patriot Advanced Capability-3 production rates, and demand for High Mobility Artillery Rocket System (HIMARS) and Guided Multiple Launch Rocket Systems (GMLRS).
• LMT is investing in 6th generation air dominance technologies within Skunk Works, demonstrating autonomous capabilities with the X-62A (F-16), and advancing hypersonic capabilities.
• The company expects to continue investing substantially in its people to ensure that its workforce has the technical skills necessary to succeed.

ITEM 1A. Risk Factors.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - ITEM 1A. Risk Factors section in bullet points:

• 73% of LMT's total consolidated net sales came from the U.S. Government in 2024, including 65% from the Department of Defense (DoD).
• The F-35 program represented 26% of LMT's revenue.
• A reduction in overall U.S. defense spending could have a material adverse effect on LMT's business.
• Budget uncertainty and the potential for U.S. Government shutdowns can adversely affect LMT's industry and funding for its programs.
• If appropriations are delayed or a government shutdown were to occur, LMT could be at risk of reduced orders, program cancellations, and other disruptions and nonpayment.
• LMT's contracts with the U.S. Government are conditioned upon the continuing availability of Congressional appropriations.
• The F-35 program is subject to risks related to performance, schedule, cost, and requirements, which could adversely affect LMT's performance.

ITEM 1C. Cybersecurity.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - ITEM 1C. Cybersecurity section in bullet points:

• LMT faces a multitude of cybersecurity threats, including common attacks like ransomware and denial-of-service, as well as more advanced and persistent threats from nation-state actors targeting the defense industrial base and critical infrastructure sectors.

• The company has implemented a governance structure and processes to assess, identify, manage, and report cybersecurity risks through its corporate information security organization.

• LMT complies with extensive regulations, including DFARS requirements for safeguarding controlled unclassified information (CUI) and reporting cybersecurity incidents to the DoD.

• The company has implemented cybersecurity policies and frameworks based on industry and governmental standards to align closely with DoD requirements.

• LMT is working with the DoD on assessing cybersecurity risk and developing policies and practices aimed at mitigating these risks, including supporting the development of the Cybersecurity Maturity Model Certification (CMMC) program.

• The company has developed its own practices and frameworks, such as the Intelligence Driven Defense model, to enhance its ability to identify and manage cybersecurity risks.

• LMT engages third-party services for evaluations of security controls through penetration testing, independent audits, or consulting on best practices.

• The company shares and receives threat intelligence with defense industrial base peers, government agencies, information sharing and analysis centers, and cybersecurity associations.

Properties.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - Properties section in bullet points:

• At December 31, 2024, LMT owned or leased building space at 356 locations primarily in the U.S.
• We manage or occupy 9 government-owned facilities under lease and other arrangements.
• The company had significant operations in the following locations:
  • Aeronautics: Palmdale, California; Marietta, Georgia; Greenville, South Carolina; and Fort Worth, Texas.
  • Missiles and Fire Control: Camden, Arkansas; Ocala and Orlando, Florida; Lexington, Kentucky; and Grand Prairie, Texas
  • Rotary and Mission Systems: Stratford, Connecticut; Orlando, Florida; Moorestown/Mt. Laurel, New Jersey; Owego and Syracuse, New York; Manassas, Virginia; and Mielec, Poland.
  • Space: Huntsville, Alabama; Sunnyvale, California; Denver, Colorado; Cape Canaveral, Florida; and Valley Forge, Pennsylvania.
  • Corporate activities: Bethesda, Maryland.
• At December 31, 2024, we had approximately 9 million square feet of floor space owned, leased, or utilized by business segment.

Legal Proceedings.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART I - Legal Proceedings section:

• LMT is a party to litigation and other proceedings arising from environmental protection provisions.
• The company is subject to federal, state, local, and foreign requirements for environmental protection.
• LMT has property subject to various lawsuits, proceedings, and remediation obligations due to hazardous material discharges and contaminated sites.
• The probability of the outcome of each matter having a material adverse effect on the corporation as a whole is remote.
• The company cannot predict the outcome of legal or other proceedings with certainty.
• LMT's financial exposure for environmental matters cannot be reasonably estimated in all cases.

ITEM 4. Mine Safety Disclosures.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the Mine Safety Disclosures section in bullet points:

• None of the executive officers have any family relationships with each other.
• All executive officers serve at the discretion of the Board of Directors.

Market for Registrant’s Common Equity, R.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART II - Market for Registrant’s Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities section in bullet points:

• As of January 23, 2025, Lockheed Martin (LMT) had 21,751 holders of record of its common stock.
• The company's common stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) under the symbol LMT.
• There were no sales of unregistered equity securities during the quarter ended December 31, 2024.
• As of December 31, 2024, the total remaining authorization for future common share repurchases under Lockheed Martin's share repurchase program was $9.3 billion.
• In October 2024, the Board of Directors authorized an increase to the program by $3.0 billion.
• The company closes its books and records on the last Sunday of each month, except for December, which aligns with its fiscal year-end on December 31.

Management’s Discussion and Analysis of.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART II - Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations section in bullet points:

• In 2024, 73% of LMT's $71.0 billion in net sales were from the U.S. Government.
• 65% of LMT's U.S. Government revenue in 2024 came from the Department of Defense (DoD).
• 26% of LMT's net sales in 2024 came from international customers, including foreign military sales (FMS) contracted through the U.S. Government.
• 1% of LMT's net sales in 2024 came from U.S. commercial and other customers.

Note: These bullet points only include concrete facts and do not include opinions or analysis.

Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART II - Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk section of LMT's financial report, formatted as bullet points:

• The estimated fair value of LMT's outstanding debt was $20.2 billion at December 31, 2024.
• The outstanding principal amount of debt, including short-term and long-term debt, was $21.6 billion at December 31, 2024.
• A 10% change in the level of interest rates would not have a material impact on the fair value of LMT's outstanding debt at December 31, 2024.
• The aggregate notional amount of LMT's outstanding interest rate swaps was $1.3 billion at both December 31, 2024 and 2023.
• The aggregate notional amount of LMT's outstanding foreign currency hedges at December 31, 2024 was $7.5 billion, and at December 31, 2023 was $6.5 billion.
• A 10% unfavorable change in the level of interest rates would have a material impact on the fair value of LMT's derivative instruments.

Financial Statements and Supplementary D.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART II - Financial Statements and Supplementary Data section in bullet points:

• The audit was conducted by Ernst & Young LLP, a public accounting firm registered with the PCAOB.
• The audit was performed in accordance with the standards of the PCAOB, which require reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
• The opinion on the financial statements is that they present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Lockheed Martin Corporation at December 31, 2024 and 2023, and the results of its operations and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2024.
• The audit included evaluating the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall presentation of the financial statements.
• The critical audit matters communicated to the audit committee relate to accounts or disclosures that are material to the financial statements and involved challenging, subjective, or complex judgments.
• The audit was conducted for the period ended December 31, 2024, and the report was dated January 28, 2025.

Legal Proceedings.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART II - Legal Proceedings section:

• The company is a party to various legal proceedings, including environmental matters and claims related to businesses previously owned.

• The probability of material adverse effects on the company due to these matters is considered remote.

• The company follows a process to estimate reasonably possible losses or ranges of loss in individual legal proceedings.

• A total contract value with the MTA was $1.4 billion, with $600 million paid to the company.

• The MTA is seeking damages of approximately $150 million from the company.

• The company disputes the MTA's allegations and is defending against them.

• An investigation by sureties on a performance bond concluded that the MTA's termination of the contract was improper.

• A declaratory judgment action was amended to include claims for monetary damages against the MTA of approximately $100 million.

• The matter was taken under submission by the District Court in December 2014, after a five-week bench trial.

Controls and Procedures.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART II - Controls and Procedures section, formatted as bullet points:

• The evaluation of LMT's disclosure controls and procedures was performed with senior management participation and concluded to be effective as of December 31, 2024.
• The CEO and CFO concluded that LMT's internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2024.
• The assessment of internal control over financial reporting was based on the 2013 framework set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
• There were no changes in internal control over financial reporting identified during the evaluation period that materially affected or are reasonably likely to affect it.
• An independent registered public accounting firm issued a report stating that LMT maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2024.

ITEM 10. Directors, Executive Officers a.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART III - ITEM 10. Directors, Executive Officers and Corporate Governance in bullet points:

• The company has had a written code of ethics in place since its formation in 1995.
• The code applies to all employees, including the principal executive officer, principal financial officer, and principal accounting officer and controller, as well as members of the Board of Directors.
• A copy of the Code of Ethics and Business Conduct is available on the company's investor relations website (www.lockheedmartin.com/investor).
• Printed copies of the code can be obtained without charge by contacting Investor Relations at Lockheed Martin Corporation.
• The company is required to disclose any change to or waiver from its Code of Ethics and Business Conduct for its Chief Executive Officer and senior financial officers.
• The company has adopted an insider trading policy governing the purchase, sale, and other disposition of its securities.

Security Ownership of Certain Beneficial.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART III - Security Ownership of Certain Beneficial Owners and Management and Related Stockholder Matters in bullet points:

• As of December 31, 2024, Lockheed Martin Corporation had 1,589,955 shares granted as restricted stock units (RSUs) and 723,136 shares that could be earned pursuant to grants of performance stock units (PSUs).

• The company has two equity compensation plans: the Lockheed Martin Corporation 2020 Incentive Performance Award Plan (2020 IPA Plan) and the Lockheed Martin Corporation Amended and Restated Directors Equity Plan (Directors Plan).

• As of December 31, 2024, there are 4,979,206 shares available for future issuance under the 2020 IPA Plan as options, stock appreciation rights, restricted stock awards, RSUs or PSUs.

• The company has a Deferred Management Incentive Compensation Plan (DMICP) that allows employees to defer annual incentive bonuses and Long-Term Incentive Performance (LTIP) payments.

• As of December 31, 2024, there are 360,774 shares available for future issuance under the Directors Plan as stock options and stock units.
